title-group.article-title: Small-Sample DIF Estimation Using SIBTEST, Cochran’s Z, and Log-Linear Smoothing

article-meta.aff: 1The Pennsylvania State University, University Park, USA

author-notes.corresp: Pui-Wa Lei, The Pennsylvania State University, 140 CEDAR Building, University Park, PA 16802, USA. Email: puiwa@psu.edu

abstract.p: Minimum sample sizes of about 200 to 250 per group are often recommended for differential item functioning (DIF) analyses. However, there are times when sample sizes for one or both groups of interest are smaller than 200 due to practical constraints. This study attempts to examine the performance of Simultaneous Item Bias Test (SIBTEST), Cochran’s Z test, and log-linear smoothing with these methods in DIF detection accuracy at a number of small-sample and ability distribution combinations. Effects of item parameters and DIF magnitudes are also investigated. Results show that when ability distributions between groups are identical, Type I error for these DIF methods can be adequately controlled at all sample sizes, and their power to detect a large amount of unidirectional DIF can be tolerably high (power > .6) when sample size is not too small (at least 100 per group). When ability distributions are different, Type I inflation is higher for easier items and larger sample sizes, and power depends on DIF direction. Log-linear smoothing with SIBTEST tends to lower both Type I error rate and power. The effect of smoothing with Cochran’s Z test is not as consistent. Implications of the findings are discussed.

body.p: Minimum sample sizes of about 200 to 250 per group are often recommended for differential item functioning (DIF) analyses using nonparametric methods or larger using parametric methods. However, there are times when sample sizes for one or both groups of interest are smaller than 200 due to practical constraints. As summarized by Fidalgo, Ferreres, and Muñiz (2004), large-sample sizes are particularly difficult to obtain in translation-adaptation studies. For example, Azocar, Areán, Miranda, and Muñoz (2001) examined DIF for the translated Spanish version of the Beck Depression Inventory. While the reference group (English-speaking sample) had 237 participants, the focal group (the Spanish-speaking sample) only had 55 participants. Similarly, Orlando and Marshall (2002) studied DIF for the translated Spanish version of the Posttraumatic Stress Disorder checklist. There were 284 English speakers in the reference group and only 102 Spanish speakers in the focal group. In addition, studies involving students with disabilities are likely to have small-sample sizes (Buzick & Stone, 2011; Sireci, 2009). In such studies, the sample size for the focal group (students with disabilities) is typically small. For instance, Stone, Cook, Laitusis, and Cline (2010) used DIF to investigate the impact of testing accommodations for students who were blind or visually impaired. Although the reference group (students without disabilities) was extremely large (n > 30,000) in the DIF analyses, the focal groups (students who were blind or visually impaired) were rather small (n = 74, 98, 105, and 141). Given the fact that DIF analyses, which were primarily developed to address the concern of item bias in large-scale achievement tests, have been adopted in small-sample situations, there is a need to evaluate how DIF methods perform with small-sample sizes (Witarsa, 2003).

Several previous studies have examined the performance of nonparametric DIF methods under small-sample conditions (e.g., Fidalgo et al., 2004; Puhan, Moses, Yu, & Dorans, 2009). Unfortunately, the definition of small sample differs across studies, and it is still unclear what methods might work at sample sizes smaller than 200 per group. This study attempts to examine the performance of several seemingly promising methods informed by the current literature at a number of small-sample and ability distribution combinations. Effects of item parameters and DIF magnitudes on the accuracy of DIF detection are also investigated.

Under small-sample conditions, nonparametric or contingency table–based methods should, in theory, perform better than parametric or item response theory (IRT) model–based methods in DIF detection. Methods that have been examined under small-sample conditions include Mantel–Haenszel (MH; Holland & Thayer, 1988) and its various modifications. Samples of 200 to 250 per group are recommended for the standard MH method (Clauser & Mazor, 1998). Zwick, Thayer, and Lewis (1999, 2000) proposed an empirical Bayes’s MH method for small-sample DIF analysis, and it was found to be more powerful than the standard MH method but at the expense of inflated Type I error (Zwick & Thayer, 2002). Other modifications such as exact MH chi-square test (Parshall & Miller, 1995) and jackknife test based on common odds ratio (Camilli & Smith, 1990) also did not show any clear advantage over the standard MH method.

With similar sample-size requirements, Simultaneous Item Bias Test (SIBTEST; Shealy & Stout, 1993) performed similarly to MH in Type I error control when there was no impact (i.e., means of ability distributions are the same between groups) but better than MH when there was impact (Roussos & Stout, 1996). This was because a regression correction was used in SIBTEST to adjust for bias due to possible difference in ability distributions (Jiang & Stout, 1998).

Bolt and Gierl (2006) applied the same regression correction to other nonparametric methods documented in Marascuilo and Slaughter (1981). They found that Cochran’s Z test with regression correction performed similarly to SIBTEST in Type I error control but better than SIBTEST in power of detecting unidirectional DIF when the sample size was small. However, the smallest sample size they examined was 500/500, larger than the commonly recommended minimum sample sizes (e.g., Clauser & Mazor, 1998; Mazor, Clauser, & Hambleton, 1992).

Cochran’s Z test with regression correction is very similar to SIBTEST. They differ in ways to weigh the difference between the reference and focal groups in conditional adjusted proportion correct for the studied item. The Appendix presents formulas for DIF (also referred to as bias by some authors), weights, and standard error for Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST, side by side, to show their similarities and differences. For Cochran’s Z test with regression correction, proportion of the reference- or focal-group examinees in a given matching test score group who answered the studied item correctly (i.e., pRj or pFj) is simply replaced by its regression-corrected counterpart (

The weights used in SIBTEST are relative frequencies for the matching test score groups either based on the focal group or pooled across reference and focal groups (the latter is presented in the appendix and used in this study). According to Bolt and Gierl (2006), the weights used in Cochran’s Z test are inversely proportional to the expected standard error of the conditional difference. As such, Cochran’s Z test should, in theory, be more powerful statistically than SIBTEST (Bolt & Gierl, 2006).

In search of ways to improve the small-sample performance of DIF methods, smoothing has also been applied with SIBTEST and Cochran’s Z test. In small-sample conditions, sample frequency distributions can be very bumpy, and smoothing is often used to reduce sampling fluctuations and produce smoother curves. Two smoothing methods, kernel smoothing and log-linear smoothing, have been incorporated in DIF methods. Kernel smoothing is essentially a type of local averaging. A smoothing parameter that is inversely related to sample size is used to control the amount of smoothing in kernel smoothing. Log-linear smoothing employs polynomial log-linear models to smooth the curves and can preserve a specific number of moments of the original distribution by specifying the proper order of the polynomials used in the model. For more detailed discussions of kernel smoothing and log-linear smoothing, see Ramsay (1991) and Holland and Thayer (1987), respectively.

Douglas, Stout, and DiBello (1996) used kernel smoothing to smooth matching test score distributions as well as conditional proportion correct distributions for studied items for SIBTEST. In all sample-size conditions they examined (250/250, 1,000/1,000, 1,600/1,600), kernel-smoothed SIBTEST did not show any advantage with respect to global DIF, which is represented by a global DIF index across all ability levels. In terms of local DIF, which refers to local estimation and inference of DIF at a chosen ability interval, kernel-smoothed SIBTEST showed a little higher Type I error rate than did the unsmoothed version, but its Type I error inflation was slight. The advantage of smoothing SIBTEST was in reducing root mean square error for local DIF estimation and improving power for highly localized DIF hypotheses. For common applications of DIF analysis, however, global DIF detection is often of most interest.

Zheng, Gierl, and Cui (2010) used kernel smoothing on Cochran’s Z test and found that it consistently produced higher power rates than the unsmoothed counterpart, with or without regression correction. In terms of Type I error control, the authors found that the kernel-smoothed Cochran’s Z test tended to be liberal whereas the (unsmoothed) Cochran’s Z test with regression correction tended to be conservative as sample size increased when there was impact. However, Zheng et al. did not examine sample sizes smaller than 500 per group.

Puhan et al. (2009) used log-linear smoothing with SIBTEST and investigated seven sample-size conditions in the ratios of 50/300, 75/300, 100/300, 150/300, 200/300, 300/700, and 700/2,100 for the focal/reference groups. The authors compared variability and “bias” of DIF estimates produced by the unsmoothed and smoothed SIBTEST methods. Their “true” DIF parameters were estimated from a large existing data set, from which the smaller samples were drawn with replacement. They found that smoothing number-correct score distributions resulted in reduced random error and “bias” of DIF estimates for most studied items, especially in the small-sample-size conditions. However, they did not investigate whether the difference was large enough to lead to different DIF classification decisions.

In general, smoothing appears to have potential for small-sample DIF estimation. According to Puhan et al. (2009), some of their prior analyses showed that kernel smoothing led to similar results as log-linear smoothing in all sample-size conditions, and kernel smoothing took considerably more computing time than log-linear smoothing. Therefore, only log-linear smoothing is examined in the present study.

In summary, the primary purpose of the present study is to systematically investigate the performance of SIBTEST, Cochran’s Z test, and log-linear smoothing with these methods for small-sample DIF estimation. Because the regression correction for impact seems to influence DIF detection (Bolt & Gierl, 2006), both Cochran’s Z tests, with and without regression correction, are examined. In total, six DIF estimation procedures are compared in terms of their DIF classification results. That is, three estimation methods (Cochran’s Z with regression correction, Cochran’s Z without regression correction, and SIBTEST) are crossed with two smoothing conditions (log-linear smoothing and no smoothing). In practice, a dichotomous decision about each studied item needs to be made. This kind of decision is often based on statistical test results, sometimes in conjunction with DIF size estimates. Thus, the correct and incorrect rejection rates of DIF test results were evaluated and the DIF size estimates produced by the different DIF methods were reported.

sec.title: Manipulated Factors
sec.p: Sample sizes, ability distributions, magnitudes of DIF, as well as item parameters of studied items were believed to influence the accuracy of DIF detection. The first factor manipulated was sample size. After reviewing some applied DIF studies in real testing situations, equal and unequal sample sizes were included between the reference (Nr) and focal (Nf) groups. Sample sizes for the focal group that have been examined in previous small-sample DIF simulation studies1 ranged from 25 to 500 (Zumbo & Witarsa, 2004), from 50 to 100 (Fidalgo et al., 2004), and from 25 to 2,000 (Parshall & Miller, 1995); whereas reference-group sizes ranged from 1 to 20 (majority ≤ 4) times that of the focal-group size. Given that the present study focused on DIF detection with small-sample sizes, the largest sample size considered was 250 (slightly larger than the commonly recommended minimum) and the smallest sample size was 25 (the smallest that has been studied). A total of eight sample-size conditions were manipulated: Nr/Nf of 250/250, 100/100, 50/50, and 25/25 for the equal sample-size condition and 250/100, 100/50, 100/25, and 50/25 for the unequal condition. The range of selected sample sizes was similar to that used in the translation-adaptation studies mentioned in the previous section. The selected ratios of reference-group/focal-group sizes were similar to the majority of DIF simulation studies.

The second factor manipulated was ability distribution. In most simulation studies, only means of the ability distributions were manipulated for the reference and focal groups (e.g., Clauser, Mazor, & Hambleton, 1991; Donoghue & Allen, 1993; Zwick, Donoghue, & Grima, 1993). Bolt and Gierl (2006) and Zheng et al. (2010), however, found that different standard deviations (SDs) of the ability distributions for the two groups did affect DIF estimation. Four ability distribution conditions were thus considered: (a) N(0,1) for both the reference and focal groups, where N stands for a normal distribution with mean and variance parameters in parentheses; (b) N(0,1) and N(−1,1) for the reference and focal groups, respectively; (c) N(0,1) and N(0,2) for the reference and focal groups, respectively; and (d) N(0,1) and N(−1,2) for the reference and focal groups, respectively.

Because the authors were interested in examining the effect of item parameters in addition to DIF magnitude, they used the same item parameters studied by Zwick, Thayer, and Wingersky (1994). The authors focused on items that showed no-DIF or unidirectional DIF because the DIF methods examined in the present study were not designed for nonunidirectional DIF. Table 1 presents the parameters for the studied items as well as practical DIF effect sizes (as measured by signed item difference in the sample or SIDS; Meade, 2010) for the unidirectional DIF items based on the four different focal-group distributions. Using Gierl and Bolt’s (2001) criteria (|effect size| < .05 is considered negligible, between .05 and .1 moderate, and ≥.1 large), the unidirectional DIF items contained small to large amounts of DIF (absolute values of SIDS ranged from .036 to .166). Half of the DIF items favored the reference group and the other half favored the focal group. There were 16 no-DIF and 16 unidirectional DIF items, a total of 32 studied items. For DIF and no-DIF items, item discrimination and difficulty parameters were varied from high to low while the pseudo-guessing parameter was held constant at .15. For each of the studied items, the same 24-item matching test with item parameters estimated from an American College Testing (ACT) mathematics test was used (see Table 2 for their descriptive statistics). The total test length was held constant at 25. All matching test items were free of DIF, and the percentage of DIF items was not manipulated.

sec.title: Procedures
sec.p:
Item responses of the studied sample sizes were generated using a three-parameter logistic model based on the item parameters and ability distributions mentioned earlier. Each studied item was analyzed with six procedures: three estimation methods (Cochran’s Z with regression correction, Cochran’s Z without regression correction, and SIBTEST) crossed with two smoothing conditions (log-linear smoothing and no smoothing). DIF test statistics for Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST were computed using the computational formulas shown in the Appendix. An item was flagged as a DIF item if the absolute value of the observed test statistic was greater than the standard normal critical value at the nominal alpha level (i.e., 1.96 for the .05 alpha level). For Cochran’s Z with regression correction, the pRj and pFj for Cochran’s Z test were replaced by the regression-corrected

For the smoothed methods, the conditional frequency distribution of correct responses for the studied item, conditional on matching test scores, was smoothed separately for each of the reference and focal groups before the DIF test statistics were calculated. That is, smoothed pRj and pFj or

, where appropriate, were used instead of the unsmoothed ones in the calculation of the smoothed DIF test statistics. Four-moment log-linear smoothing was performed for all studied items using the SAS macro provided by Moses and von Davier (2006).

In the calculation of Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST, matched score groups with frequencies less than two in either the focal or reference group were collapsed with the adjacent score group that was closer to the center of the matching test score distribution to maximize the use of observations. Starting from the two tails and stopping at the center of the matching test score distribution, frequencies (i.e., NRj and NFj) in each score group (j) were checked, and collapsed if necessary, until there were at least two observations in each of the focal and reference groups for each matched score group (i.e., NRj≥ 2 and NFj≥ 2 for all j). This aggressive matching approach was necessary because of the small samples examined in this study. The same matching approach was used for all six DIF methods. For each of the DIF condition (no-DIF or unidirectional DIF), we had 8 (sample size) × 4 (ability distribution) × 16 (studied item) × 6 (DIF method) fully crossed conditions.

Performances of the DIF procedures were evaluated by proportions of correct rejections (power) and proportions of incorrect rejections (Type I error) out of 200 replications at a nominal alpha level of .05. Type I error rates were tabulated based on no-DIF items. Correct rejection rates were calculated for unidirectional DIF items. Average rejection rates and average absolute values of DIF estimates were first examined across studied items by true DIF size (no-DIF, small/moderate DIF or |SIDS| < .1, and large DIF or |SIDS| ≥ .1) to gauge the overall performance of the DIF methods under different combinations of sample-size and ability distribution conditions. DIF estimates produced by the different DIF methods were also inspected because sometimes they were used in conjunction with statistical test results to classify magnitudes of DIF. Absolute values of DIF estimates were taken before averaging so that positive and negative values would not cancel each other out. Then for each DIF condition (no-DIF or unidirectional DIF), η2 was computed for each of the studied factors, including item parameters and true DIF size (as measured by absolute values of SIDS) where appropriate, and their interactions to identify factors that explained at least a moderate amount of variation (η2 > .06) in rejection rates for further investigation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The DIF methods produced test results for nearly all studied conditions (4 ability distributions × 8 sample sizes × 200 replications × 32 studied items). There were several occasions (7 out of the 4 × 8 × 200 × 32 = 204,800 total combinations) in the very small-sample conditions (Nr/Nf = 25/25 or 50/25) in which all participants in both groups answered a few very easy studied items (no-DIF items with b = −1.95, and DIF item with bs = −1.3 and −2) correctly and resulted in zero standard errors. These cases were not included in further analysis.

Effective sample sizes used to calculate the test statistics were not 100% of the original samples in some instances due to the inability to match all participants from unequal-mean distributions or small-sample conditions. Table 3 presents the average (over replications) proportions of participants used by sample-size and distribution conditions. The lowest average proportion of participants successfully matched was .92 in the 100/25 sample-size and unequal-mean equal-variance distribution conditions.

sec.title: Incorrect Rejection Rate and DIF Estimates for No-DIF Items
sec.p: The average Type I error rate (proportion of false positives) was first examined at a nominal alpha level of .05 and average absolute values of DIF estimates across studied items for each combination of sample size, ability distribution, and DIF method. Complete Type I error and DIF estimate results by studied items are available on request. Table 4 highlights in boldface the conditions under which average Type I error rates were within the 99% interval around the expected .05 level based on 200 replications without adjusting for the number of studied items (i.e., >.01 and <.10). This liberal range was considered as tolerable because the sample-size and distribution conditions in this study were quite challenging for DIF methods. When population ability distributions were the same for the focal and reference groups, Type I error rates were tolerably small for all DIF methods examined across all sample sizes. When the groups had the same population mean but different variances, Type I error rates were also generally tolerably small with a few exceptions at larger sample sizes (e.g., 250/250 for the unsmoothed methods and 250/100 for smoothed Z tests).

caption.p: Average Type I Error Rates and DIF Estimates for No-DIF Items.

fn.p: Note: DIF = differential item functioning; Z-NRC = Cochran’s Z with no regression correction; Z-RC = Cochran’s Z with regression correction; SIBTEST = Simultaneous Item Bias Test. Table entries are Type I error rates (absolute values of DIF estimates). Average Type I error rates >.01 and <.10 are bolded. Reference group ~ N(0,1).

sec.p: However, when population means were different for the focal and reference groups, Type I error rates for the DIF methods were largely inflated beyond an acceptable level, and the magnitude of inflation tended to be more severe with a larger total sample size. Employing the same regression correction used in SIBTEST was helpful in lowering Type I error inflation due to the difference in population means for Cochran’s Z test when sample size was not too small (≥50 for each group when population variances were equal, or ≥25 for each group when population variances were unequal).

Log-linear smoothing appeared to work differently for SIBTEST and Cochran’s Z test. It lowered the Type I error rate for SIBTEST in nearly all sample-size and ability distribution conditions (with an exception at sample sizes 250/250 and when ability distributions differed in mean only). The effect of smoothing was not as consistent for Cochran’s Z test. It appeared to lower the Type I error rate for Cochran’s Z test when population means were equal (except at the 250/100 sample-size condition) or sample sizes were equal and small (≤100/100) when population means were different.

Among the DIF methods examined, smoothed SIBTEST generally provided lower average Type I error rates than did the other methods holding sample-size and ability distribution conditions constant. However, Type I error rates for smoothed SIBTEST tended to be lower than the nominal level when population ability means were equal.

When population ability means were equal, the average absolute values of DIF estimates appeared to be similar across DIF methods, and they were less than .1 across sample-size conditions. That is, it was not very likely that non-DIF items would be classified as large DIF items by these methods in equal ability mean conditions. However, absolute values of DIF estimates tended to increase with impact and smaller sample sizes for all six DIF methods. Average absolute values of DIF estimates were larger than .1 for smaller total sample sizes (≤125 for methods with regression correction, and ≤150 for methods without regression correction) when ability distribution means were unequal. Regression correction for Cochran’s Z test generally reduced the DIF size estimates somewhat when there was impact with few exceptions (very small-sample sizes and ability distributions differed in mean only). Smoothing did not appear to have a consistent effect in reducing DIF size estimates for these DIF methods.

Proportion of variance in Type I error rates due to DIF method and smoothing, ability distribution, sample size, item difficulty and discrimination of the studied items, and their interactions was calculated to determine the factors that affected Type I error rates. Factors that accounted for at least a moderate amount of variation (η2≥ .06) were further examined. Ability distribution (η2 = .218), item difficulty (η2 = .139), and their two-way interaction (η2 = .130) accounted for the largest proportion of variation in Type I error rates. Sample size (η2 = .096), its two-way interaction with item difficulty (η2 = .088) and with ability distribution (η2 = .076), and their three-way interaction (η2 = .061) also accounted for a moderate amount of variation. DIF method and smoothing only accounted for a small amount of variation (η2 = .035). The model including all the manipulated factors and up to four-way interactions explained 98% of the total variance in Type I error rates.

Figure 1 displays the three-way interaction pattern among item difficulty, ability distribution, and sample size on Type I error rates. Interestingly, equal ability distributions in both mean and variance resulted in adequate average Type I error rates regardless of item difficulty parameters and sample sizes. However, item difficulty parameters and sample sizes appeared to make a difference when ability distributions were not identical for focal and reference groups. When ability distributions differed in variances only, average Type I error rates were tolerably small for most conditions except for easy items (b≤ 0) at larger total sample sizes (n≥350). Type I error rates were largely inflated when ability distributions were different in means, with larger inflation associated with easier items, larger total sample sizes, and difference in population ability variances. In the worst combination of the largest sample size (250/250) and unequal ability distributions in both mean and variance, the average Type I error rate for the easiest items (b = −1.95) was close to .90.

caption.p: Interaction among ability distribution, item difficulty, and sample size on Type I error rates.

sec.title: Correct Rejection Rate and DIF Estimates for Unidirectional DIF Items
sec.p: Tables 5 and 6 display the average correct rejection rates and average absolute values of DIF estimates across unidirectional DIF items for small/moderate and large effect sizes of DIF, respectively. Complete correct rejection rate and DIF estimate results by studied items are available on request. Conditions under which Type I error control was inadequate are given in boldface in the tables because power was likely inflated due to Type I error inflation. When Type I error rates were reasonably controlled, the DIF methods were largely underpowered to detect small/moderate unidirectional DIF items (average power < .55), and their power to detect large unidirectional DIF items was reasonably high (average power > .85) when sample size was 250 for each group. When ability distribution means were equal and Type I error was tolerably controlled, power of the unsmoothed methods for detecting large unidirectional DIF was acceptably high (power > .60) when sample size was at least 100 for each group. As expected from the pattern of Type I error rates, the smoothed methods were generally slightly less powerful than the unsmoothed counterparts, and the smoothed SIBTEST was less powerful than the smoothed Cochran’s Z test with regression correction in detecting unidirectional DIF items.

caption.p: Average Power Rates and DIF Estimates for Small/Moderate Unidirectional DIF Items.

Table entries are power rates (absolute values of DIF estimates). Cells that do not yield reasonable Type I error control are bolded. Reference group ~ N(0,1).

Table entries are power rates (absolute values of DIF estimates). Cells that do not yield reasonable Type I error control are bolded. Reference group ~ N(0,1).

sec.p: DIF estimates by all six DIF methods for the large DIF items correctly fell into the large category (>.1) in all combinations of sample sizes and ability distributions. However, DIF estimates for the small/moderate DIF items tended to fall incorrectly into the large category when ability means, variances, or both were unequal and with smaller total sample sizes. When ability distributions were identical, DIF estimates tended to reflect the magnitude of small/moderate DIF accurately (absolute values of DIF estimates < .1) with larger total sample sizes (≥100). When both ability means and variances were different, the DIF estimates fell incorrectly into the large category regardless of sample size or DIF method.

When ability means were equal, DIF estimates appeared to be largely similar between methods holding smoothing constant, and smoothing appeared to reduce the magnitudes of DIF estimates somewhat. When ability means were unequal and holding smoothing constant, DIF methods with regression correction appeared to produce somewhat smaller DIF estimates than methods without regression correction, and Cochran’s Z test with regression correction was largely similar to SIBTEST in their DIF estimates (except perhaps when sample sizes were unequal, smoothed SIBTEST tended to produce slightly smaller DIF estimates than smoothed Cochran’s Z test with regression correction did). When ability means were different, smoothing did not appear to have a consistent effect on DIF estimates for the small/moderate DIF items but tended to reduce the magnitude of DIF estimates somewhat for large DIF items.

Proportion of variance due to DIF method and smoothing, ability distribution, sample size, true DIF effect size (as measured by absolute value of SIDS), focal-group item difficulty, whether the studied item favored the reference group (or DIF direction), and their possible interactions was computed to determine the factors that affected correct rejection rates of unidirectional DIF items. True DIF effect size (η2 = .107), sample size (η2 = .256), whether the studied item favored the reference group (or DIF direction, η2 = .247), and its interaction with ability distribution (η2 = .096) accounted for a substantial amount of variance in correct rejection rates of unidirectional DIF items. Again, DIF method and smoothing only accounted for a small amount of variation (η2 = .033). The model including all the manipulated factors and up to four-way interactions explained 98% of the total variance in correct rejection rates.

As expected, average correct rejection rates of unidirectional DIF items increased as total sample sizes increased (from .162 to .628 as total sample size increased from 50 to 500) or true DIF effect sizes increased (about .312 increase in correct rejection rate per .1 increase in absolute value of SIDS, holding other factors constant). Figure 2 shows the interaction between ability distribution and DIF direction on correct rejection rates of unidirectional DIF items. When ability distributions were identical, there was essentially no difference between DIF directions in correct rejection rates. When ability distributions were different between groups, the DIF methods had a higher correct rejection rate of items that favored the reference group. In other words, when the direction of difference in group ability means was consistent with the direction of DIF (i.e., the item was easier for the more able group) or when the favored group’s ability levels were less variable, the DIF procedures appeared to be more powerful.

caption.p: Interaction between ability distribution and DIF direction on correct rejection rates of unidirectional DIF items.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Sample sizes available for DIF analysis are not always large. In fact, many applied DIF analyses were conducted with samples smaller than the recommended sizes of 200 to 250 per group. It is conceivable that the number of available participants who belong to different minority groups, have certain disabilities, or speak a language other than English at home from a school population is usually small, especially when the total participating sample is small and no oversampling is planned. This study intends to find out which of the DIF methods that are supposed to have the potential to work well under small samples as informed by the literature, if any, performs acceptably well in terms of making correct DIF classifications at different small-sample and ability distribution conditions. The DIF methods examined include SIBTEST, Cochran’s Z test, Cochran’s Z test with regression correction, and their log-linearly smoothed counterparts.

Results of this study suggest that DIF analysis using these methods under small samples (at least 25 in each group) can perform satisfactorily in Type I error control, using the definition of acceptable range (i.e., >.01 and <.1), when ability distributions between groups are the same. When ability distributions are unequal in mean, variance, or both, Type I error tends to be more severely inflated with larger total sample sizes and for easier items. Zheng et al. (2010) also observed similar Type I error inflation patterns for the Cochran’s Z test without regression correction when there was impact (i.e., ability distribution means are different).

Type I inflation appears to be much worse when ability distributions are unequal in mean than when they are unequal in variance only. Incorporating the regression correction in Cochran’s Z test seems to be generally helpful in reducing Type I inflation (and DIF magnitude estimates) when ability distribution means are unequal. However, Type I inflation is still unacceptably high when there is impact for the unsmoothed regression-corrected DIF methods in all sample-size conditions. With larger sample sizes (n≥500 per group), different studied item parameters (bs = −.75 and .75), and slightly different ability distribution conditions, Zheng et al. (2010) found that regression-corrected Cochran’s Z test provided adequate Type I error control and tended to be conservative. The poor performance of the unsmoothed DIF methods in Type I error control under impact found in this study is mainly due to a number of very easy studied items. Poorer matching of the focal and reference groups because of smaller samples used in this study may also explain the discrepant performance of the regression-corrected Cochran’s Z test in Type I error control found in this study and Zheng et al.’s study.

Puhan et al. (2009) reported reduced bias and variability of DIF estimates with log-linearly smoothed SIBTEST for small-sample sizes, but they did not examine the accuracy of DIF classification. The results show that log-linear smoothing is generally helpful in reducing Type I inflation for SIBTEST when ability distributions are different between groups. However, smoothing renders SIBTEST somewhat conservative (i.e., slightly lower Type I error rate than expected) and less powerful when ability distributions are identical. That is, log-linear smoothing tends to improve the accuracy of SIBTEST in identifying no-DIF items while sacrificing some accuracy in identifying DIF items.

The effect of log-linear smoothing for Cochran’s Z test (with or without regression correction) in reducing Type I inflation, however, is not very consistent. Smoothing appears to reduce Type I error rates for Cochran’s Z test when sample sizes are equal and small (≤100 each group). When Type I inflation is tolerably low, log-linearly smoothed Cochran’s Z test tends to have lower power than does the unsmoothed counterpart. The finding about smoothing with Cochran’s Z test appears to be inconsistent with that of Zheng et al. (2010), who found that smoothed Cochran’s Z test produced higher power than did the unsmoothed counterpart. This inconsistency could be due to the different smoothing methods used: log-linear smoothing in this study versus kernel smoothing in Zheng et al.

Between Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST, Bolt and Gierl (2006) suggested that Cochran’s Z test should be more powerful and inflate Type I more than does SIBTEST. Their projected trend is largely supported by the results, especially for the smoothed methods. However, differences among methods are generally small. Other factors such as ability distribution, sample size, and item parameter characteristics appear to matter more in the accuracy of DIF classification.

When ability distributions between groups are identical, Type I error control is generally acceptable though power may be low if total sample size is small. More importantly, when ability distributions are the same, there are no anomalies due to item parameters (e.g., higher Type I error rate for easier items) or DIF direction (e.g., higher power for items that favored the reference group). In this case, unsmoothed methods are preferred to the smoothed ones because the unsmoothed methods tend to provide acceptable Type I error control and higher power. Even in this optimal ability distribution condition, sample size of at least 100 per group is recommended for the unsmoothed methods if power of at least .60 to detect a large unidirectional DIF effect size is desired. Of course, a larger sample size is required if higher power or smaller DIF effect size is of interest. When there is no impact, the common minimum sample size recommendation of 200 to 250 per group appears to be adequate for the DIF methods examined here if power of at least .8 to detect a large unidirectional DIF effect size is preferred.

When ability distributions are different, especially in mean, smoothed SIBTEST performs the best in Type I error control. However, power for smoothed SIBTEST is generally lower than the other methods examined here. Smoothed SIBTEST might be recommended when ability distributions differ in variance only and sample size is not too small (n = 250 per group). In this case, smoothed SIBTEST might provide adequate Type I error control and reasonably high power (around .85) to detect large unidirectional DIF.

It appears that Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST, with or without log-linear smoothing, should not be used when ability distribution means are grossly different between groups (by 1 SD of the reference group), at least for sample sizes no larger than 250 per group, unless perhaps the test contains no extremely easy items. Under large impact, these DIF methods lose control of Type I error, and Type I inflation tends to become worse with larger sample sizes (Finch, 2005, also observed the same pattern for SIBTEST with sample sizes, 500/100 and 500/500). Under this condition, many items may be flagged for showing DIF. Unfortunately, one cannot tell with high confidence whether they are true positives or false positives. Because real tests likely contain items of a wide range of difficulty levels, further work on improving the correction for bias due to impact for Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST may be necessary if reference and focal groups are likely to be largely different in their ability means in practice.

Furthermore, it is interesting to note that when there is impact, Type I error inflation is lower despite larger DIF estimates for the no-DIF items with smaller sample sizes. It appears that larger DIF estimates do not necessarily lead to higher rejection rates. Standard error estimates appear to have accounted for the larger sampling fluctuations due to smaller samples but do not seem to account for errors due to impact. Perhaps Type I error control of the DIF tests can be improved by incorporating a correction for impact in the standard error estimator, a larger adjustment factor for the DIF size estimator, or both. Alternatively, if one would like to rely on DIF magnitude estimates for DIF classification decisions, perhaps more lenient cutoffs should be used when sample sizes are small and ability distribution means are different.

In practice, difference in true ability distributions between the focal and reference groups would not be known but could be gauged from the difference in observed score distributions. Frequency distributions of observed total scores for the groups could be compared to get an idea of whether the ability distributions for the groups would be similar or largely different. If the observed frequency distributions are similar, especially in central location, then the proposed DIF methods could probably be used. Otherwise, Type I error inflation and excessive DIF size estimate might be concerns.

Findings of this study should be interpreted in light of the specific conditions examined. The findings may not generalize to other DIF methods, smoothing methods, sample-size conditions, or item or test characteristics. Because different ability distributions for the focal and reference groups, especially in mean, appear to make a large difference in Type I error control and DIF size estimates for the DIF methods examined here, future studies can investigate DIF classification accuracy of these methods with more impact sizes to find out the maximum impact size under which their Type I error control and DIF size estimate would be acceptable.

Moreover, four moments of the empirical item characteristic curves were preserved for the studied items in the log-linearly smoothed methods. Puhan (2011) recently discovered that preserving a smaller number of moments might be better than preserving a larger number of moments in reducing random equating errors when sample size is small. It might be beneficial to examine the effect of preserving a smaller number of moments (e.g., 2 or 3) in log-linear smoothing with Cochran’s Z test and SIBTEST for small samples in the future to see if the advantage of preserving fewer moments found in equating generalizes to DIF studies. Because the performance of the smoothed Cochran’s Z test relative to the unsmoothed counterpart found in this study appears to be different from that reported by Zheng et al. (2010), who used kernel smoothing rather than log-linear smoothing, comparing the effect of using different smoothing methods may also be informative.

Last, one may wonder whether nonparametric DIF methods such SIBTEST or MH would truly perform better than parametric DIF methods such as IRT–likelihood ratio (IRT-LR) test when sample sizes are small. Paek and Wilson (2011) showed that both the Rasch DIF method and MH could provide good Type I error control under small-sample-size conditions (100/100, 200/200, and 300/300) and believe that the Rasch DIF method could be more powerful than the MH procedure when the Rasch model fits the data. For more highly parameterized IRT models (two- or three-parameter logistic models), Finch (2005) found similar Type I error rates for SIBTEST and IRT-LR when there was no impact and no anchor item contamination using sample sizes of 100/500 and 500/500. When there was impact (ability mean difference = 1) but no anchor item contamination, Type I error rate was slightly inflated for SIBTEST, and the inflation was worse for shorter tests or larger sample sizes. When there was contamination on the matching test, however, Type I error was more inflated for IRT-LR than for SIBTEST. Similarly, Pei and Li (2010) found that IRT-LR and SIBTEST showed satisfactory Type I error rate under all ability distribution conditions (mean difference = 0 or 0.5, and focal-group variance = 1, 2, or 3) at sample sizes 300/300 (the smallest they examined), although IRT-LR tended to be slightly conservative (.02 < Type I < .04) and insensitive to ability distributions while SIBTEST tended to be slightly liberal (.05 ≤ Type I < .08) and a little sensitive to differences in ability means and variances.

However, a recent dissertation by Lopez (2012) demonstrated that when DIF-free matching tests were used and test length was reasonably long (e.g., 30), Type I error rates were acceptable (≤.08) for crossing-SIBTEST (Li & Stout, 1996) with mild impact (.5) but inflated (ranging from .13 to .26) for IRT-LR regardless of impact using sample sizes of 250/250 or larger. Lopez’s findings appear to be inconsistent with those found by the other studies reviewed above. Unfortunately, it is difficult to compare findings across studies that vary different factors, different levels of factors, or both, besides sample size. The authors hesitantly conclude from results of these studies2 that there is no strong evidence to suggest that nonparametric methods like SIBTEST perform worse or better than parametric methods like IRT-LR in Type I error control with sample sizes that are similar to or higher than the larger sample-size conditions (≥100 per group). This conclusion is based on results under similar (across studies) and near optimal conditions for IRT-LR and SIBTEST: correct model and DIF-free matching tests for IRT-LR and reasonably long matching test and mild impact for SIBTEST. Nevertheless, no generalization of this cross-study comparison is warranted. Future studies should directly compare the performance of parametric and nonparametric DIF methods under a number of relevant conditions to reach a more definite conclusion about the advantage or disadvantage of using nonparametric DIF methods for small-sample sizes.

Because definitions of small samples vary widely, the authors selected studies that included sample sizes smaller than the commonly recommended 200 for the focal group.

The authors did a thorough search for studies comparing nonparametric differential item functioning (DIF) methods (such as Simultaneous Item Bias Test [SIBTEST] and Mantel–Haenszel [MH]) and parametric DIF methods (such as item response theory–likelihood ratio [IRT-LR] test) using small-sample sizes. Because parametric DIF methods generally require large-sample size, most (if not all) DIF studies using small-sample sizes tend to adopt nonparametric methods. Therefore, the search only resulted in a few studies that include small focal-group sample sizes that are similar to the larger sample sizes.
